marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Letters concerning business transactions of the society, including a letter from Charles C. Jones, Jr., accepting an invitation to speak and a resolution of thanks to him; a letter relative to the formation of a Ladies Literary and Art Society; a memorial to the Georgia legislature containing a brief history of the society; a letter by Governor Henry D. McDaniel on the fiftieth anniversary of the society; and clippings giving accounts of the society's activities.
The Gee family resided in Halifax County, North Carolina. Joseph Gee resided in Wilcox Co.. Alabama, beginning around 1816.

Collection comprises business and legal correspondence of Sterling, Nevill, Charles, and Joseph Gee, although Nevill Gee has greatest prominence. Joseph Gee was extensively engaged in cotton planting. Nevill also owned one or more plantations in Alabama, which Joseph supervised. In November 1824, Joseph Gee died suddenly, leaving a large estate (including 47 slaves) intestate. Nevill's son, Sterling, immediately went to Alabama to supervise his father's plantations and administer his uncle's estate. The early letters refer to the business devolving from these circumstances. Sterling apparently remained in Alabama for an indefinite period, looking after his family's interests, and engaging in his own land speculation. Sterling's brother Charles also resided in Alabama, where at one time he worked as a school teacher. The latter letters deal almost entirely with business matters and law suits. Other topics include early settlement in Alabama; prices for slaves, land, cotton, crops; and the local economic structure.
Collection contains land deeds and agreements contracted by the Gentry and Camp families of Spartanburg and Laurens Counties, S.C.
Georgia and South Carolina travel diary,
William Gerhardt was principal of the Western Carolina Male Academy in 1855-1856.

Papers of William Gerhardt, teacher and clergyman, include several teaching contracts, programs for Examination Day exercises and a schedule for classes at Western Carolina Male Academy, 1855-1857, a list of contributors to a German church in the United States, some genealogical information, and several letters in German.
Surgeon in the Confederate Army, from Selma (Dallas Co.), Alabama.
Collection includes family and Civil War letters of James T. Gee, along with Gee's father's letters containing comments on the panic of 1837 and the elections of 1840 and 1844.
Resident of Gap Civil, Ashe County, North Carolina.

Business, financial, and personal correspondence of a North Carolina family, primarily reflecting the affairs of Allen and Richard C. Gentry. These papers include material concerning land dealings, tobacco planting, local politics and the Know-Nothing party (1857), and the Civil War. Among four soldiers' letters is a letter from Levi C. Gentry, written while he was a prisoner of war at Johnson's Island, Ohio.
Georgia Air-Line Railroad Company account book,
Account book of the Georgia Airline Railroad Company, showing the stockes and stockholders, 1858, and salt prices in the Confederate States of America, 1864.
Resident of Doctor Town (Wayne Co.), Ga.

Family letters of five brothers, Asa, David, Furniaful, George, and John, Confederate soliders, telling of living conditions in the army and of military activities in Georgia and Mississippi. Included also is a bit of folk poetry.
Edmund Gibbes was a physician residing in Charleston, S.C. prior to the Civl War.

Scattered personal correspondence concerning family affairs and the sale of slaves of a wealthy Charleston physician engaged in some undefined occupation during the Civil War, probably blockade running. In an 1863 letter, Gibbes' wife, Amelia, wrote of how badly he had treated her. In 1860 Gibbes was listed as possessing over $15,000 in real estate and 25 enslaved persons.
German-American Mutual Loan and Building Association,
German-American Mutual Loan and Building Association scrapbook,
Cancelled stock certificates in the German-American Loan Building Association.
German-American Mutual Loan and Building Association.
